Red Flags For Anti-Aging Products

Click each card to to review the red flags and solutions

Are safety claims provided? e.g., FDA related claims, clinical tested.

  • FDA does not have the authority to approve supplements before sale, so the claims of FDA approval are false.
  • 'Clinically tested' doesn't guarantee safety.
  • The website claims 'clinical trials aren't fully published yet.' This sounds scientific, but it's just an excuse for why you can't find any real proof.

Does the website rely heavily on emotional or testimonial language?

Beware of websites that rely heavily on emotional appeals and testimonials rather than facts. Scammers use this to manipulate your emotions and trust, without real evidence. Don't let the emotional words convince you - always seek factual information.

Is the description vague despite sounding scientific?

Be mindful of descriptions that employ scientific terms but lack clear explanations. If the information is too vague or overly complicated, it could be a red flag. Search the name of the company or the product online to verify its credibility.
